filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of 20 of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. These designs illustrate the Old Testament and are arranged according to the passages illustrated. They are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
The Bible had an enormous influence on Blake’s work as both artist and poet. Among his many and complex responses to that text are water color drawings. The present group of 20 is selected from a sequence of about 80 biblical water colors of similar size Blake painted for Thomas Butts between c. 1800 and c. 1806. These designs emphasize interactions between the human and the divine. In works such as Ezekiel’s Wheels and David Delivered Out of Many Waters, the interaction is revelatory or redemptive. In other designs, including Pestilence: The Death of the First-Born, the relationship between God and humankind devolves into punishment and destruction.
This group of 20 water colors is the first installment in our publication of a large selection of Blake’s water color drawings illustrating the Bible. In coming months we will publish a group of New Testament illustrations also from the series executed for Butts. Later we will add early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, including Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes of c. 1824.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1800-1803; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 158, titled "Samson Bursting His Bonds" (11s. to "Butts," thus indicating that the lot was bought-in if Butts was the vendor); sold from the Butts collection, Foster & Son auction, London, 29 June 1853, lot 105, titled "Samson and Delilah" (12s. to John Clark Strange); the dealer Francis Harvey, offered in his catalogue of c. 1865 for £2.10s.; George A. Smith by 1876; sold from Smith's collection, Christie's, 16 July 1880, lot 103 (£2.10s. to the dealer James Rimell & Sons); William Bell Scott; sold from Scott's collection, Sotheby's, 21 April 1885, lot 184 (£6 to the dealer John Pearson); offered in Pearson's 1885 catalogue 59 for £12.12s.; Thomas Glen Arthur by 1890; sold from Arthur's collection, Sotheby's, 20 March 1914, lot 51, titled "Samson and Delilah" (£23.3s. to the dealer James Tregaskis); J. L. Field; sold Sotheby's, 30 July 1946, lot 464 (£1,100 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, possibly acting for Mrs. Landon K. Thorne); bequeathed by Thorne in 1974 to the Pierpont Morgan Library (now Morgan Library and Museum).

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates Judges 16:10-12. Samson, an almost-nude male, dominates the center of the design. The bonds he breaks are ropes tied in knots on his wrists and ankles. He has short, curly hair and a beard. Samson faces forward and slightly right, though he bends his head back to look up at the female figure to his right. His arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms out and fingers spread; his left leg is bent at the knee and his right leg is extended backward and on tiptoe. His mouth may be slightly open. Samson sits on what appears to be a chair covered with cloth which also covers his genitals. To the right stands a female figure, presumably Delilah. She faces right and slightly forward, though turns her head to look to the left and down at Samson. She wears a gown and has a hat or braided headdress atop her curly hair. Her arms are bent, with the left arm bent upward, and fingers spread. Her left palm faces out, her right away from the viewer. She crouches on the seat on which Samson also sits, with her left leg bent and her right leg extended backward and on tiptoe. To the left of Samson are three male figures, probably guards or soldiers, seen from behind. They may wear armor and helmets and appear to be fleeing the scene. They all bend forward slightly, two with their left legs extended back and on tiptoe and their right legs bent to climb stairs. Their left arms are raised horizontally, fingers spread. The legs of the leftmost figure are not visible. The scene appears to take place in a room, possibly a prison cell, which has stairs in the left background and a curtain in the right background.

component.illusobjdesc: Dominating the design is the almost-nude figure of Samson, with his genitals covered by a fold of cloth. He has short, curly hair and a beard. Samson faces forward and slightly right, though he bends his head back to look up at the female figure to his right. His arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms out and fingers spread; his left leg is bent at the knee and his right leg is extended backward and on tiptoe. His mouth may be slightly open. Samson sits on what appears to be a chair covered with cloth.
The bonds that Samson breaks from are ropes tied in knots on his wrists and ankles. He has apparently just broken his bonds.
Samson sits on what appears to be a chair covered with cloth.

To Samson's right stands a female figure, presumably Delilah. She faces right and slightly forward, though turns her head to look to the left and down at Samson. She wears a gown and has a hat or braided headdress atop her curly hair. Her arms are bent, with the left arm bent upward, and fingers spread. Her left palm faces up, her right away from the viewer. She crouches on the seat on which Samson also sits, with her left leg bent and her right leg extended backward and on tiptoe. Her right arm rests on her left upper leg.

To the left of Samson are three male figures, probably guards or soldiers, seen from behind. They may wear armor and helmets and appear to be fleeing the scene. They all bend forward slightly, two with their left legs extended back and on tiptoe and their right legs bent to climb stairs. Their left arms are raised horizontally, fingers spread. The legs of the leftmost figure are not visible.
The scene appears to take place in a room, perhaps a prison cell, which has (stone?) stairs in the left background and a curtain in the right background.
